VALUE: this is a comment. they help to explain code!
leaving menu (e.g. to join the game)
use these 3 blocks for testing time quickly (change the 0s to adjust extra hour,min,sec)
battleTimer is a 4 minute cycle (when it reaches 3:59 it resets to 0:00)
splatmeetTimer is a 6 hour cycle (when it reaches 0:00:00 it resets to 5:59:59)
displayTimer alternates between being out of battle (3:59 to 3:00, the first 1 minutes of each cycle)
and being in battle (2:59 to 0:00, the last 2 minutes of each cycle)
to make it back to 3min:2min, change the above 0 to 1, and the -1 below to -2
should fix for daylight savings. IF THIS DIDN'T FIX IT, change -1 to 1
SNT = SplatmeetNextTime. In the end it displays the full message e.g. "1am EST"
to calculate the goal time just add the current hour to the remaining hour amount
if they are in japan then just use the premade "japan time" costume
get the time number right and am/pm
USA times need to be changed each daylight savings
"y" is the goal y position of the slider
cycle through each of the 12 songs and it's synced with everyone

sounds.name: sp3 Till Depth Do Us Part

VALUE: stop sound by handing the sound to a clone and then deleting the clone
stop a sound by adding a minus - and then the sound name
the days since 2000 block is the same for everyone in the world because it's of EST time
click is a special key because it needs to "mouse down" block
if the key is not pressed then it's neither held nor hit
we got the lowest cloud id in "i1", and only if the player's id is even lower than that, switch their team
just copy the original key names
prepare all the lists related to Keybinds and currently-pressed-keys
figuring out how many players on each team so we can join the team with fewer players
displayTimer alternates between being out of battle (3:59 to 3:00, the first 1 minutes of each cycle)
and being in battle (2:59 to 0:00, the last 2 minutes of each cycle)
FPS+deltatime script (deltatime is the split-second of time betweet each frame)
round to 4 decimal places, and 2 decimal places
to detect afk, it just joins all your currently pressed keys/mouse position,
and compares it with the keys that were pressed on the previous frame.
if they don't change for 2 minutes, you're afk and kicked.
if your pressed keys/mouse stays the same for too long then it disconnects you
"days since 2000" block is very useful because it's accurate like the timer, and stays the same across timezones
saves the last time when they were different
doing the multiplying/dividing/rounding so the number is only about 8 digits long and its not like 5634.23333333333333...
if the current time is over x minutes than the last saved time, then it will disconnect
to get an amount of time in terms of "days since 2000" then do it like this:
divide 1/24 to get 1 hour, (1/24)/60 to get 1 minute, then multiply by 3 to get 3 minutes
set the oldkeys to the nowkeys so it can be compared on the next frame
if the key is pressed then it's definitely being held
when the key first gets hit, its Hit bit is set to 1, then it decreases every frame to 0.1
update all the bits for whether each key is being held/hit or not
Press P to pause/unpause. Press O to advance 1 frame.
allows the game to progress another frame, but pause immediately afterwards
it'll show the thumbnail, delete clones, and clear all long lists to save data.
Broadcast to all sprites so they can update their frame
first set map to 0 then ask for a random map
makes the offline timer start at 11 seconds before battle starts
get the average map# in i1 and the average second# in i2
correct the map by setting it to what all the other players have (find 2 that match)
we will adjust our map to be the 1st player's map (i1)...
...unless i1's is not the same as i2 or i3, then i1 must be wrong, and we will use the i2 map instead
correct the seconds timer by undoing the difference from what everybody else has
if a team has 2 or more team members than the other team, we will switch the team of the player with the lowest cloud id
press 7+8 as admin to save/reset the project
then save, then press 9 to put the records back
i1 and i2 are goal cam x and cam y. i3 is the friction
Let's find what color the player is standing on and store it in PStandColor
get the (2 closest) rows and columns the player is standing on
get the 4 tile colors based on the rows and columns and store the colors in PStandTiles
Based on the 4 colors the player is standing on, figure out which "1 main color" they're standing on
if at least 2 of the tiles are of the player's own color, we will say the player is on its own color
now we know what color ink the player is standing on, stored in "PStandColor"
and we can use that to make them move faster, take damage, etc. depending on what color they're standing on
add (column, row, color) to the import list
splatroller is 50 pixels out from the player's hands, and 43 pixels out on either side lengthwise
they held for long enough, this will be a charge swing
if the player is swimming in their own color, move normally. otherwise move slowly
this block checks the player's x position and determines if they're colliding or in a zone. PlayerIsColliding? returns 0 or 1
if after the new movement, the player is colliding, or they are in the enemy spawn, then move them out of it
check collision one more time. if they're still colliding, then they must be stuck in a wall, but instead of killing them just move them
mathematical direction in case player is offscreen while using charge bow
smooth turning script. makes PlayerDirection gradually turn towards i1
All below is when the specials are active
the only sound script for cloud
spawn at your platform but can't control yet
also gain/lose health depending on color of ink standing on
turns players into human if they shoot while being a squid
spawn at your platform but can't control yet
DESTINATION COORDINATES ARE IN PXvel, Pyvel
get speed to get to destination in exactly 40 frames
clone# 1 and up are cloud player clones
i'm not using custom blocks to do this because custom blocks cause a bit of lag
cloud clones delete themselves when their player leaves
clouddatamodified list has all cloud data of all players.
iiL# (item in list number) is the item# in the list just before the clone's data.
then offset iiL# by each number for each piece of data and put it in the variable for the clone to use.
increase kills for player by checking if the player's killagent is the player
if this item can possibly damage the player
determine if each player is onscreen or not
make this player focused (display their name) if they just came on screen, or if there is no highlighted player yet
and not if they're an enemy swimming in their own ink
stop this script if offscreen (except if theyre using a bow or threw a bomb)
swaying side to side with brush
checks if the sound change has been updated (modified is different than raw), which is the queue to play the sound. then makes them the same again
if they do an emote make them highlighted
if the player is hovering their mouse over another player, highlight that player
smooth enlarging while turning from squid
paintballs from cloud players uses the same Change technique as the sounds
paintballs from cloud players uses the same Change technique as the sounds
their animframe has to be 2,3,4, 7,8 or 9
paintballs from cloud players uses the same Change technique as the sounds
paintballs from cloud players uses the same Change technique as the sounds
paintballs from cloud players uses the same Change technique as the sounds
ghost them out if they're not moving
i2 is acting as TileWidth here
destination will be stored in PXvel PYvel
Create extra clones when there are more players online
if the current number of the focusedplayer is more/less than the actual number of players, reset it
displaying all players on the end screen
simulating the spinning of the player clones
winning team, frequent high speeds (they are excited cause they won)
losing team spins slower + stops more (they are depressed)
using PX,PY,PZ to represent the scroll x of the three dresser rows
the only sound script for cloud
you can reduce a lot of lag just by making repeat-scripts run once every 2 3 4 or 5 frames instead of constantly every frame
check for landing (if it reached goal)
while flying, if it is an enemy paintball, constantly check if hitting the player
check the coordinates to see if it is in the player's hitbox
if so, the player will be hit
paintball land (do this when it lands)
find the tile number the paintball landed on
first paint the center tile, then try painting the 8 tiles surrounding it. this creates a nice random splash pattern
now turn the paintball into a splash particle
test if it can fall into the water
thanks to nanakouTV for this code that detects if the enemy is within the range of the kiIIer wail!
other sprites add to this list to make the clones
put paintball at nose of item
run the tick once when the clone is created so it isn't behind 1 frame
the mod -360 gets rid of the annoying white on the edge glitch
sets color at the beginning of battle setup, making it depend on

VALUE: This is a similar map stamping script as the regular one, but simpler so it's easier to understand
choose the right tile width based on the size of the map
Start at the right position so the map is centered
slow but looks better (not by much)

mutation.proccode: Process All Lists Data   :   1.Prepare NewTiles 2.Prepare StaticTiles 3.Load StaticTiles 4.Load NewTiles

VALUE: The main block that handles the painting and cloud painting systems.
(part 0 small extra thing): keep clearing the NewTiles list and keep it at max 30 length (but only 20 get sent to the cloud each frame)
(also clear the half painted tiles list) (turn half-size circles into real painted squares)
Part 1: register newly painted tiles and prepare these new tiles to be sent to the cloud
if the tilestopaint list has things
we are painting this tile and also encoding it into the New10Tiles list to be sent to the cloud.
i1 is if it's a valid tile (it can be painted)
within map boundaries, it is valid so far
but make it not land on spawn pads, holes
if it's a valid tile, let's paint it
that was the easy part. now we need to "encode" the tile into the NewTiles list to send it to the cloud.
create the 1 digit number that represents 2 tiles. the result is in myColor
if even tile location, convert it to its odd counterpart
if the tile is in the list, delete it (it will re-add it so it's fresh)
finally add the new location and color combo digit to the list. this will be saved to the cloud in the "Cloud" sprite, and decoded in "Tiles" sprite
Part 2: prepare our static list to be sent to the cloud
1 in every 3 frames (since the cloud only gets set 1 in 3 frames anyway)
add the 2 pieces of data 10 times. first their location (3 digits) then their color (1 digit)
this variable keeps track of which tile list position it last sent to the cloud
make sure it's in between the length of the painted list
now we're going to add all the tiles to add to the cloud into this static10tiles list
1st part: location. add 999 to it so it's always 4 digits long
new script to try to get through the empty tiles faster
Part 3: load and use all players' static map data from the cloud
Part 4: Load and use all players' Newtile data from the cloud
getting ready to go through this map data. the increase of each tile is 4 because each tile's data is 4 digits long
this code below is so complicated. but understand that it wasn't like this originally. originally it was only the two red blocks above, and then gradually evolved.
figuring out which tile costume to switch to based on the tiles that are around it.
this makes them look better, having rounded edges instead of just being squares
first get the colors of the 8 tiles surrounding the current tile
these 4 if blocks prevent edge tiles from joining with tiles on the opposite edge
if the tiles to the up and down match it, or left and right match it, then paint it a solid square
if none of the edge tiles are the same color, paint a circle
diagonal pattern of slightly bright and dark tiles
finally we have the final costume of this tile and we stamp it
now we need to fill in the corners (try breaking this script off of this block to see what it's really doing)
it checks each of the 4 corners. if the corner tile+the two tiles next to it are the opposite color, then it fills in that corner.
all done! :) the tile is fancily painted, and now we just go back and have to repeat this for the next tile, the next tile, and so on
new: make the color change every 5 minutes with the battle timer, in increments of 61 (a prime number so it's pretty random)

mutation.proccode: Process All Lists Data   :   1.Prepare NewTiles 2.Prepare StaticTiles 3.Load StaticTiles 4.Load NewTiles

VALUE: main code from griffpatch's RPG tutorial episodes 2,3
THE MOST IMPORTANT VARIABLE OF ALL TIME. try changing it
the higher the number, the fewer tiles need to be stamped, but you can't see as far while playing
old was 36. new is 45. it's 36% faster now!
if you asked me to describe each piece of all the code below, it would not be easy for me
because it really does look messy. But it wasn't always this way. It was very simply stamping
the tiles, and then gradually I kept adding more blocks to it. So don't feel upset if
you can't understand it. You should watch griffpatch's Tile RPG episodes 2 and 3 first to learn it
these 3 variables gx,gy,gidx, are hard to understand
but the 4 variables myRow, myColumn, myMapDataItem#, and myColor, are very easy to understand and use, right?
it sets up myRow and myColumn and then increases each by 1 as it stamps each tile
myMapDataItem# is the item # in the MapData list that corresponds to that row and column on the grid. and yes it is the same as gidx.
each item in the list is just one number (0 1 or 2) that represents the color of the tile. so we can just get the color if we know the item #.
if this tile is valid, on the map
then stamp the paint color on top of that. two methods:
fast: just paint squares, no rounded edges
rounded edges. slower but looks better
these 4 blocks can make a costume go anywhere
fancy shadows on edges of map

VALUE: 20 is the thickness of the rail edge
create two hole zones for the 4 "corners" of the ship
groups of the numbers 1 through 8, each group random order
The more custom blocks you use, the laggier it is.
So unfortunately to reduce lag I have to combine everything into one long hard-to-read custom block.
I tried breaking up each section with comments though.
store all the old player-timers in a list so they can be compared with the new ones later
get all the new player-data (from the 8 cloud variables) into the CloudOtherPlayers list
if the cloud variable stayed the same as it was previously. don't do anything
or the first 4 digits are the ID and if they match the player's ID, then the data is the player's. don't do anything
decodes the numbers from the "data" variable and puts the results in the list "clouddecoded"
Part 1: pulling apart the individual numbered data from the long variable
variables: i1: current digit# in data. i2: length of each data item's digits. i3: number of data item (1 to 25). i4: name of data item.
set i3 to 4 to be ready to scan the number type data (which starts at 5)
figuring out how many digits each data item is (i2)

STRING1: ,map static tile data,map new tile data,

VALUE: pulling the digits into the return variable. we figured out how long it should be (i2)
if the ID's match then this is the player's data and there's no use continuing because we dno't need to decode the player's own data (they already have it)
undoing the offset that was done when encoding the data. subtracting the 2000s etc
part 2: decoding the numbered data and inserting that into clouddecoded
then make use of the info (now in the CloudDecoded list)
use the data just gotten into the Decoded list, and find out which player this data belongs to
the data is the player's. don't do anything
empty/incomplete cloud variable. don't do anything
this player is already in the game, since the data has a player ID# already in the game.
now update that player's data in the list
this is a new player joining. now add their data to the end of the list

STRING2: がナワバリバトルオンラインに参加した!

VALUE: By now we have all the data of online players in the CloudOtherPlayersDataRaw list.
Fancy step: modify (smoothen out) all players' position data etc and some sounds stuff too into the Modified list
modifying, meaning tweening the choppy 10FPS data to make it smooth suitable for 30FPS
first transfer over all data that is NOT supposed to be modified
now let's modify all the data that is supposed to be modified
special Tween block for many values
get the starting and ending x values, and divide 2 ways between them so they get split up for each frame
get the starting and ending direction values, and use these math scripts to get a smooth turning transition
based on the timers we previously got, check to see which players are inactive and remove those players
Timers: This is how players are determined for being online/offline.
First, look at the timer of a player
if a player's timer is still the same as the previous frame, increase their staleness
otherwise the player is actively changing their timer and their staleness is reset
now check if their staleness is over 150 frames.
this means that the player has been inactive for 5 seconds, and will be deleted
delete all the lists data associated with that player
shift the counter back 1 to compensate for this player that was deleted
The more custom blocks you use, the laggier it is.
So unfortunately to reduce lag I have to combine everything into one long custom block.
EACH PIECE OF DATA AND THE LENGTH IT SHOULD ALWAYS BE (in parentheses)
now join on static and new tiles lists

CloudOtherPlayersDataRaw: the list that will contain the received data of every other player
CloudOtherPlayersDataModified: the same data as above but tweened to be smooth in 30FPS
CloudOtherPlayersTimers: this list has 1 number for each player - the always-changing timer value
CloudOtherPlayersStaleness: this list has 1 number for each player - if the number reaches 70, the player is offline.
if a player's "timer" is the same as on the previous frame, their staleness increases.
